Goal: Create an chrome extension that was able to search for videos in large playlists.
There were already a few extensions that did this in the store, but none of them worked to my liking.
My extension is able to search video titles by word instead of as an exact phrase.
It has a searchable dropdown list of channel names you can also filter by.
The videos show the thumbnail
The channel and title search filters are persistent per playlist across devices
Custom lazy loading that only loads 25 or so videos at a time in the view, while being able to search the whole playlist.
Playlists that take longer than 1 second to load have the video metadata saved for faster retrieval the next time the extension is opened.
The purpose of this project was to both revive the git-radar project, and learn golang.

git-radar was a project to give a 'heads up display' for Git in your bash prompt. It no longer sees any active development and it was slow on larger git repositories so I wanted to recreate it in a language other than bash, add new features, and increase performance.

I chose to work with Golang because it was of interest to me at the time, and it makes running concurrent code easy, which allowed me to increase performance by up to about a factor of 5 in certain situations

Goal: To make a web based Tetris game that mimics the behaviour and rules of the classic NES Tetris game as closely as possible, with the ability to send a unique URL to a friend so that they are able to play the same sequence of pieces so you can compare your scores. The scores would be listed on the page for that game.

Currently the game is in development. The game itself is playable but there are some bugs and issues I plan to address, and scores for the game are not saved or listed on the page. I plan to solve this by saving scores to a database, and using PHP to generate the game page with the scores listed.
